column4: also known in English as Archangel and Archangelsk
column5: is a city and the administrative center of Arkhangelsk Oblast
column6: in the north of Western Russia. It lies on both banks of the Northern Dvina near its exit into the White Sea. The city spreads for over 40 kilometers (25 mi) along the banks of the river and numerous islands of its delta. Arkhangelsk was the chief seaport of medieval and early modern Russia until 1703 (when it was replaced by Saint Petersburg). A 1
column7: 133-kilometer-long (704 mi) railway runs from Arkhangelsk to Moscow via Vologda and Yaroslavl
column8: and air travel is served by the Talagi Airport and a smaller Vaskovo Airport. As of the 2010 Census

column1: The arms of the city display the Archangel Michael in the act of defeating the Devil. Legend states that this victory took place near where the city stands
column3: and that Michael still stands watch over the city to prevent the Devil's return.

column1: Vikings knew the area around Arkhangelsk as Bjarmaland. Ohthere of Hålogaland told circa 890 of  his travels in an area by a river and the White Sea with many buildings. This was probably the place later known as Arkhangelsk. According to Snorri Sturluson
column2: Vikings led by Thorir Hund raided this area in 1027.

column3: right next to present-day Arkhangelsk. It was probably buried in the beginning of the 12th century
column4: and contained articles that may have been up to two hundred years old at that time.

column1: The main trade center of the area at that time was Kholmogory
column2: located 75 kilometers (47 mi) southeast of Arkhangelsk
column3: up the Dvina River
column4: about 10 kilometers (6.2 mi) downstream from where the Pinega River flows into the Dvina. Written sources indicate that Kholmogory existed early in the 12th century
column5: but there is no archeological material to illuminate the early history of the town. It is not known whether the origin of this settlement was Russian
column6: or if it goes back to pre-Russian times. In the center of the small town (or Gorodok) that is there today is a large mound of building remains and river sand
column7: but it has not been archeologically excavated.

column1: The area of Arkhangelsk came to be important in the rivalry between Norwegian and Russian interests in the northern areas. From Novgorod
column2: the spectrum of Russian interest was extended far north to the Kola Peninsula in the 12th century. However
column3: here Norway enforced taxes and rights to the fur trade. A compromise agreement entered in 1251 was soon broken.In 1411
column4: Yakov Stepanovich from Novgorod went to attack Northern Norway. This was the beginning of a series of clashes. In 1419
column5: Norwegian ships with five hundred soldiers entered the White Sea. The "Murmaners"
column6: as the Norwegians were called (cf. Murmansk)
column7: plundered many Russian settlements along the coast
column8: among them the Archangel Michael Monastery.Novgorod managed to drive the Norwegians back. However
column9: in 1478 the area was taken over by Ivan III and passed to the Grand Duchy of Moscow with the rest of the Novgorod Republic.

column3: and the Netherlands ===

column1: Three English ships set out to find the Northeast passage to China in 1553; two disappeared
column2: and one ended up in the White Sea
column3: eventually coming across the area of Arkhangelsk. Ivan the Terrible found out about this
column4: and brokered a trade agreement with the ship's captain
column5: Richard Chancellor. Trade privileges were granted to English merchants in 1555
column6: leading to the founding of the Company of Merchant Adventurers
column7: which began sending ships annually into the estuary of the Northern Dvina. Dutch merchants also started bringing their ships into the White Sea from the 1560s. Scottish and English merchants also traded in the 16th century; however
column8: by the 17th century it was mainly the Dutch that sailed to the White Sea area.

column1: In 1584 Ivan ordered the founding of New Kholmogory (which would later be renamed after the nearby Archangel Michael Monastery). At the time access to the Baltic Sea was still mostly controlled by Sweden
column2: so while Arkhangelsk was icebound in winter
column3: it remained Moscow's almost sole link to the sea-trade. Local inhabitants
column5: were the first to explore trade routes to Northern Siberia as far as the trans-Urals city of Mangazeya and beyond. In December 1613
column7: Arkhangelsk was besieged by Polish-Lithuanian marauders commanded by Stanislaw Jasinski (Lisowczycy)
column8: who failed to capture the fortified town. In 1619 and in 1637 a fire broke out
column9: and the complete city was burned down.

column2: Peter the Great ordered the creation of a state shipyard in Arkhangelsk. A year later the ships Svyatoye Prorochestvo (Holy Prophecy)
column3: Apostol Pavel (Apostle Paul)
column4: and the yacht Svyatoy Pyotr (Saint Peter) were sailing in the White Sea. However
column5: he also realized that Arkhangelsk would always be limited as a port due to the five months of ice cover
column6: and after a successful campaign against Swedish armies in the Baltic area
column7: he founded St. Petersburg in May 1703. Nonetheless
column8: Arkhangelsk continued to be an important naval base and maritime centre in the Russian north.

column2: Peter the Great decreed that Arkhangelsk should no longer accept goods that amounted to more than was sufficient for the town (for so-called domestic consumption). It was due to the Tsar's will to shift all international marine trade to St. Petersburg. This factor greatly contributed  to the deterioration of Arkhangelsk that continued up to 1762 when this decree was canceled.

column1: Arkhangelsk declined in the 18th century as the Baltic trade became ever more important.
In the early years of the 19th century
column2: the arrest and prolonged detention by Russian authorities of John Bellingham
column3: an English export representative based at Arkhangelsk
column4: was the indirect cause of Bellingham later assassinating British Prime Minister Spencer Perceval.

column1: Arkhangelsk's economy revived at the end of the 19th century when a railway to Moscow was completed and timber became a major export. The city resisted Bolshevik rule from 1918 to 1920 and was a stronghold of the anti-Bolshevik White Army supported by the military intervention of British-led Entente forces along an Allied expedition
column2: including a North American contingent known as the Polar Bear Expedition.  It was also the scene of Mudyug concentration camp.
Arkhangelsk was a major port of entry for Allied aid. During World War II
column3: the city became known in the West as one of the two main destinations (along with Murmansk) of the Arctic Convoys bringing supplies in to assist the Soviet Union. During Operation Barbarossa
column4: the German invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941
column5: Arkhangelsk was one of two cities (the other being Astrakhan) selected to mark the envisioned eastern limit of Nazi control. This military operation was to be halted at this A-A line but never reached it as the German forces failed to capture either of the two cities and also failed to capture Moscow.

now open year-round due to improvements in icebreakers. The city is primarily a center for the timber and fishing industries.

column1: Smartavia (formerly Aeroflot Nord and Nordavia) airline has its head office on the grounds of the Talagi Airport in Arkhangelsk.

Arkhangelsk was home to Pomorsky State University and Arkhangelsk State Technical University which merged with several other institutions of higher learning in 2010 to form the Northern (Arctic) Federal University.
Arkhangelsk is also home to the Northern State Medical University
column3: and a branch of the All-Russian Distance Institute of Finance and Economics.

column1: Mikhail Lomonosov came from a Pomor village near Kholmogory. A monument to him was installed to a design by Ivan Martos in 1829. A monument to Peter the Great was designed by Mark Antokolsky in 1872 and installed in 1914.
After its historic churches were destroyed during Joseph Stalin's rule
column2: the city's main extant landmarks are the fort-like Merchant Yards (1668–1684) and the New Dvina Fortress (1701–1705). The Assumption Church on the Dvina embankment (1742–1744) was rebuilt in 2004.
it was decided that the city's cathedral
column3: dedicated to the Archangel Michael
column4: which had been destroyed under the Soviets
column5: would be rebuilt. The foundation stone was laid in November 2008 by the regional Bishop Tikhon. The cathedral
column6: situated near the city's main bus station and river port
column7: is expected to be completed and consecrated in 2019.Another remarkable structure is the Arkhangelsk TV Mast
column8: a 151-meter (495 ft) tall guyed mast for FM-/TV-broadcasting built in 1964. This tubular steel mast has six crossbars equipped with gangways
column9: which run in two levels from the central mast structure out to the each of the three guys. On these crossbars there are also several antennas installed (image).

column1: An unusual example of local "vernacular architecture" was the so-called Sutyagin house. This thirteen-story
column2: 44-meter (144 ft) tall residence of the local entrepreneur Nikolay Petrovich Sutyagin was reported to be the world's
column3: or at least Russia's
column4: tallest wooden house. Constructed by Mr. Sutyagin and his family over the course of fifteen years (starting in 1992)
column5: without plans or a building permit
column6: the structure deteriorated while Mr. Sutyagin spent a few years in prison on racketeering charges. In 2008
column7: it was condemned by the city as a fire hazard
column8: and the courts ordered it to be demolished by February 1
column12: and the remainder of the building was dismantled manually by early February 2009.

column3: in particular
column5: is notable for its folklore. Until the mid-20th century
column6: fairy tales and bylinas were still performed on the daily basis by performers who became professionals. Starting from the 1890s
column7: folkloric expeditions have been organized to the White Sea area and later to other areas of the Arkhangelsk Governorate in order to write down the tales and the bylinas
column8: especially in Pomor dialects. In the 1920s
column9: mostly due to the efforts of Anna Astakhova
column10: these expeditions became systematic. By the 1960s
column11: the performing art was basically extinct. These folkloric motives and fairy tales inspired the literary works of Stepan Pisakhov and Boris Shergin
column12: who were both natives of Arkhangelsk.

column1: Arkhangelsk experiences a subarctic climate (Köppen climate classification Dfc)
column2: with long (November–March) and very cold winters and short (June–August) and cool summers. Arkhangelsk is the largest city in the world with a subarctic climate. Much of Western Calgary in Canada experiences a subarctic climate
column3: and has a much larger population
column4: but not all of the city has a subarctic climate so it doesn't count. Krasnoyarsk in Siberia also has a borderline subarctic climate with the suburbs and northern parts of the city experiencing a subarctic climate and has a population over 1 million
column5: but the whole city doesn't experience a subarctic climate so it also doesn't count.
